Detailed Description

template<typename Real>
class kaldi::CuMatrixBase< Real >

Matrix for CUDA computing.

Does the computation on the CUDA card when CUDA is compiled in and we have a suitable GPU (CuDevice::Instantiate().Enabled() == true); otherwise, does it on the CPU.

void AddRowRanges ( const CuMatrixBase< Real > &  src,
const CuArray< Int32Pair > &  indexes 
)

For each row r of this and for each column c, do (*this)(r, c) += src(j, c), where j ranges from indexes[r].first through indexes[r].second - 1.

In general indexes must be >= 0 and < src.NumRows(); but to represent an empty range you may use the pair (-1, -1) or any pair of numbers (i, j) such that i >= j.

Definition: cu-matrix.h:613
void AddToRows ( Real  alpha,
const CuArray< Real * > &  dst 
) const

For each row r of this matrix, adds it (times alpha) to the array of floats at the location given by dst[r], where dst[r] is assumed to be obtained from the RowData() function of another CuMatrix, or from CuVector::Data() (i.e.

it should point to memory on the GPU if we're using a GPU, or on the CPU otherwise). If dst[r] is NULL, does not do anything for that row. Requires that none of the memory regions pointed to by the pointers in "dst" overlap (e.g. none of the pointers should be the same).

void Cholesky ( CuMatrixBase< Real > *  inv_cholesky = NULL)

This function does sets *this to the Cholesky factor of *this (i.e.

the C satisfying *this = C C^T), and sets "inv_cholesky" (if supplied) to its inverse. *this is treated as a symmetric matrix but only the lower triangle is accessed.

Definition at line 1598 of file cu-matrix.cc.

References TpMatrix< Real >::Cholesky(), CuMatrixBase< Real >::Cholesky(), CuSpMatrix< Real >::CopyFromMat(), CuTpMatrix< Real >::CopyFromTp(), CuMatrixBase< Real >::CopyFromTp(), TpMatrix< Real >::Invert(), KALDI_ASSERT, kaldi::kNoTrans, kaldi::kTakeLower, kaldi::kTrans, kaldi::kUndefined, and CuMatrixBase< Real >::SymAddMat2().

Referenced by CuTpMatrix< Real >::Cholesky(), CuMatrixBase< Real >::Cholesky(), kaldi::TestCuMatrixCholesky(), kaldi::UnitTestCholesky(), and kaldi::UnitTestCuCholesky().

1598  {
1599  KALDI_ASSERT(this->NumRows() == this->NumCols());
1600  const int32 block_size = 64; // We can tune this.
1601 #if HAVE_CUDA == 1
1602  bool have_gpu = CuDevice::Instantiate().Enabled();
1603 #else
1604  bool have_gpu = false;
1605 #endif
1606  if (this->NumRows() == 0) {
1607  return;
1608  }
1609  if (inv_cholesky == NULL && this->NumRows() >= block_size * 2 && have_gpu) {
1610  // Even if the user did not request the inverse Cholesky, for large enough
1611  // matrices (on GPUs) it's going to be more efficient to compute it anyway
1612  // as the recursion depends on it.
1613  CuMatrix<Real> inv(this->NumRows(), this->NumCols());
1614  Cholesky(&inv);
1615  return;
1616  }
1617  if (this->NumRows() <= block_size || inv_cholesky == NULL || !have_gpu) {
1618  // Don't recurse: compute the Cholesky (and inverse Cholesky, if requested)
1619  // directly, on the CPu.
1620  int32 dim = this->NumRows();
1621  CuSpMatrix<Real> this_sp(dim, kUndefined);
1622  this_sp.CopyFromMat(*this, kTakeLower);
1623  SpMatrix<Real> this_sp_cpu(this_sp);
1624  TpMatrix<Real> C_cpu(dim);
1625  C_cpu.Cholesky(this_sp_cpu);
1626  CuTpMatrix<Real> C(C_cpu);
1627  this->CopyFromTp(C);
1628  if (inv_cholesky != NULL) {
1629  C_cpu.Invert(); // Get inverse Cholesky on CPU.
1630  C.CopyFromTp(C_cpu);
1631  inv_cholesky->CopyFromTp(C); // Copy inverse Cholesky from CPU.
1632  }
1633  return;
1634  }
1635  // At this point, if none of the other cases apply, we recurse.
1636 
1637  // The selection of dim1 is a heuristic. We could also just take half.
1638  int32 tot_dim = this->NumRows();
1639  int32 dim1;
1640  // Break it up into a whole number of blocks, for better memory alignment.
1641  // The line below, setting dim1 can be decided on a heuristic basis: from
1642  // the point of view of correctness, it can really be any value
1643  // 0 < dim1 < tot_dim.
1644  dim1 = block_size * std::max<int32>(1, tot_dim / (2 * block_size));
1645 
1646  int32 dim2 = tot_dim - dim1;
1647  CuSubMatrix<Real> this_11(*this, 0, dim1, 0, dim1),
1648  this_12(*this, 0, dim1, dim1, dim2),
1649  this_21(*this, dim1, dim2, 0, dim1),
1650  this_22(*this, dim1, dim2, dim1, dim2);
1651  CuSubMatrix<Real> inv_11(*inv_cholesky, 0, dim1, 0, dim1),
1652  inv_12(*inv_cholesky, 0, dim1, dim1, dim2),
1653  inv_21(*inv_cholesky, dim1, dim2, 0, dim1),
1654  inv_22(*inv_cholesky, dim1, dim2, dim1, dim2);
1655  /*
1656  Here is the math on block-wise Cholesky. We'll use a Matlab-like notation for blocks of a matrix,
1657  e.g. [ A B; C D ], and also for transposes, e.g. A' is the transpose of A.
1658  Let A be the input matrix; we want to compute both its Cholesky L and its inverse Cholesky, which
1659  we'll call M.
1660  OK. let L = [ L11 0; L21 L22 ] be the Cholesky factor of A.
1661  We have A = L L' = [ L11 0; L21 L22 ] * [ L11' L21'; 0 L22' ]. Multiplying it out,
1662  if A = [ A11 A12; A21 A22 ]; then
1663  A11 = L11 L11', A21 = L21 L11', A22 = L21 L21' + L22 L22', and A12 = A21'.
1664 
1665  We also want an expression for the inverse of L (we call this M).
1666  If M = [ M11 0; M21 M22 ], then it's not hard to see that
1667  M11 = inv(L11), M22 = inv(L22).
1668  We can work out M21 as follows. We know that [ L11 0; L21 L22 ] [ M11 0; M21 M22 ] = [ I 0; 0 I ].
1669  Considering the zero on the bottom of the rhs, we have: L21 M11 + L22 M21 = 0, which gives us:
1670  M21 = - L22^{-1} L21 M11 = - M22 L21 M11.
1671 
1672  Next, we want expressions for L21 and L22. From the equation A21 = L21 L11', we have:
1673  L21 = A21 inv(L11') = A21 M11'
1674  We can compute L22 and M22 recursively by doing Cholesky (and computing the inverse Cholesky)
1675  on the quantity T = (A22 - L21 L21'). [we give it the name T just for easy reference.]
1676 
1677  Computationally, we do this as follows:
1678  (1) Recurse to get L11 and M11.
1679  (2) Compute L21 = A21 M11'
1680  (3) Compute T = A22 - L21 L21'
1681  (4) Recurse on T to get L22 and M22.
1682  (5) Compute M21 = -M22 L21 M11.
1683  Next, we have to consider the in-place nature of the computation, since L overwrites A
1684  [M has its own storage, in "inv_cholesky"].
1685  We address this here:
1686  (1) is in-place [L11 replaces A11, M11 has its own storage].
1687  (2) L21 gets written where M21 belongs.
1688  (3) T replaces A22.
1689  (4) is in-place [L22 replaces T where A22 was, M22 has its own storage]
1690  (5):(a) we first compute the transpose of (L21 M11) is done in the upper part of A/L,
1691  where A12 or L12 would be. Define a temporary expression
1692  U = (L21 M11)' = M11' L21'; this goes where A12 or L12 would be.
1693  (b) copy L21 to where it should be, in *this.
1694  (c) Compute M21 = -M22 U', in the correct place for M21.
1695  (d) zero L12 and M12. */
1696 
1697  // (1) compute L11 and M11.
1698  this_11.Cholesky(&inv_11);
1699  // (2) compute L21 = A21 M11'. For now it's in the "wrong place", where M21 should be.
1700  inv_21.AddMatMat(1.0, this_21, kNoTrans, inv_11, kTrans, 0.0);
1701  // (3) compute T = A22 - L21 L21'. Note: only the lower triangle of T will be valid, but
1702  // that's OK because Cholesky will ignore the upper part.
1703  this_22.SymAddMat2(-1.0, inv_21, kNoTrans, 1.0);
1704  // (4) Recurse to compute L22 and M22.
1705  this_22.Cholesky(&inv_22);
1706  // (5)(a) compute U = M11' L21'. We use the storage of this_12 for this. Note that L21 is
1707  // currently where M21 should be.
1708  this_12.AddMatMat(1.0, inv_11, kTrans, inv_21, kTrans, 0.0);
1709  // (5)(b) copy L21 to where it should be.
1710  this_21.CopyFromMat(inv_21);
1711  // (5)(c) compute M21 = -M22 U'.
1712  inv_21.AddMatMat(-1.0, inv_22, kNoTrans, this_12, kTrans, 0.0);
1713  // (5)(d) zero L12 and M12.
1714  this_12.SetZero();
1715  inv_12.SetZero();
1716 }

void CopyRows ( const CuArray< const Real * > &  src)

Copies row r of this matrix from an array of floats at the location given by src[r], where src[r] is assumed to be obtained from the RowData() function of another CuMatrix, or from CuVector::Data() (the point is: the data it points to should be on the GPU if we're using a GPU, and on a CPU otherwise).

src.size() must equal this.NumRows(), and if any src[r] is NULL then this.Row(r) will be set to zero.

void CopyRowsFromVec ( const CuVectorBase< Real > &  v)

This function has two modes of operation.

If v.Dim() == NumRows() * NumCols(), then treats the vector as a row-by-row concatenation of a matrix and copies to *this. if v.Dim() == NumCols(), it sets each row of *this to a copy of v.

Definition: cu-matrix.h:613
void CopyToRows ( const CuArray< Real * > &  dst) const

For each row r of this matrix, copies it to the array of floats at the location given by dst[r], where dst[r] is assumed to be obtained from the RowData() function of another CuMatrix, or from CuVector::Data() (i.e.

it should point to memory on the GPU if we're using a GPU, or on the CPU otherwise). If dst[r] is NULL, does not copy anywhere. Requires that none of the memory regions pointed to by the pointers in "dst" overlap (e.g. none of the pointers should be the same).

void GroupPnormDeriv ( const CuMatrixBase< Real > &  input,
const CuMatrixBase< Real > &  output,
Real  power 
)

Calculate derivatives for the GroupPnorm function above...

if "input" is the input to the GroupPnorm function above (i.e. the "src" variable), and "output" is the result of the computation (i.e. the "this" of that function call), and *this has the same dimension as "input", then it sets each element of *this to the derivative d(output-elem)/d(input-elem) for each element of "input", where "output-elem" is whichever element of output depends on that input element.

*this = beta * *this + alpha * M M^T, for symmetric matrices.

It only updates the lower triangle of *this. It will leave the matrix asymmetric; if you need it symmetric as a regular matrix, do CopyLowerToUpper().

void AddMatMatBatched ( const Real  alpha,
std::vector< CuSubMatrix< Real > * > &  C,
const std::vector< CuSubMatrix< Real > * > &  A,
MatrixTransposeType  transA,
const std::vector< CuSubMatrix< Real > * > &  B,
MatrixTransposeType  transB,
const Real  beta 
)
friend

Does multiple matrix multiplications, executing them in parallel using cuBLAS's gemmBatched if we are using a GPU.

Vectors A, B and C must have the same length; for each i, this function executes the matrix operation C[i] = alpha * A[i](^T)*B[i](^T) + beta * C[i].
